--- Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> Quoting Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@...>:
>  
> > I agree that I would be simulating the highest
> level
> > control task related to steering and power usage. 
> The
> > methods I use, if succesful, could theoretically
> be
> > applied to a real robot, but it would be
> difficult,
> > because a fairly accurate simulation of the entire
> > real situation is required in order to perform
> > neuroevolution.  Developing this simulation is the
> > difficult part.  We cannot perform neuroevolution
> in
> > the actual vehicle, but only in a computer
> simulation.
> 
> By 'high-level' task I meant a NN that would receive
> at it's inputs 
> the bearing and distance of a target location plus
> information about 
> local obstacles. The output of the NN would then be
> a bearing and 
> speed the vehicle should go in in order to get to
> the target 
> location, but avoiding the local obstacles. A model
> can be built for 
> this task and an NN evolved for it.
>

I don't think that for desert racing the task is
separable in the way you propose, although it would
depend on the characteristics of the particular
terrain.  Would you believe I have personal experience
racing a motorcycle on the desert? :)  It's true; it
was in California in 1961.  I used to be a dirt-biker.
But my assertion is that the vehicle spends at least
50% of its time moving in a curved path.  Hence it is
more appropriate that the ANN output steering and
throttle information.  These outputs will rarely be
constant, but rather continually changing.  However, I
concede that if the obstacles are sparse, and the
vechicle large and stable, then the path might be
mostly a series of straight lines between points.

> The resultant NN is then fixed, it's a black box
> with inputs and 
> outputs, no more evolving of the NN is necessary. 

I don't think this is feasible, because the terrain
and vehicle characteristics affect the choices, even
if the outputs are desired heading and speed.
 
> We would then move onto the next task, evolving a NN
> that receives at 
> its inputs a bearing and speed the vehicle should
> move. It's outputs 
> then give controls signals for steering and drive
> motors.
> 
> When both NNs are ready they can be combined to
> create a complete 
> system. Keep in mind this is just an example
> scenario to explain my 
> point, it's not meant to be complete!
> 
> The point is that the first 'high'level' black box
> should not require 
> any further evolving in order to work in the real
> world - it can be 
> used as it is. 
> 
> The other task though would require complex models -
> e.g. to take 
> into account different surface and terrain types.
> These sort of 
> models can never be completely accurate and this
> does present a major 
> problem for evolving solutions since you need to be
> able to run many 
> trial runs automatically.

My approach combines your two levels into one.  But we
are in agreement that complex models are necessary to
evolve the 2nd level of your description.  I think
that if there is a big-budget operation, then models
of sufficient accuracy might be created.  When
combined with Darren's suggestion of randomization, a
sufficiently robust ANN might eventually evolve.


=====
Mitchell Timin
http://annevolve.sourceforge.net
